name: Group Therapy
summary: A therapeutic approach where individuals work on personal challenges within a supportive group setting guided by a trained therapist.
description: Group therapy involves one or more therapists working with several people at the same time. It provides a safe, structured environment for individuals to share experiences, gain support, and practice new behaviors. The group dynamic fosters learning from others’ perspectives, reduces isolation, and builds interpersonal skills. Sessions may be structured (e.g., skills training) or process-oriented (e.g., exploring emotions and interactions). Groups can be tailored to specific concerns, such as depression, trauma, addiction, or social skills.

contraindications: Severe antisocial behavior that disrupts group safety
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Safe and supportive when facilitated by trained therapists; potential for emotional discomfort.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong—supported by extensive clinical and research evidence across multiple conditions.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Research demonstrates effectiveness for depression, anxiety, trauma, and addiction recovery.

sections.text: Group therapy leverages interpersonal interaction, mutual support, and therapist facilitation to promote insight, coping skills, and behavioral change. Members gain perspective on their issues by hearing others’ experiences, practicing new skills, and receiving feedback in real time. The group serves as a microcosm of social interactions, allowing patients to address relational patterns in a safe environment.

sections.preparation: Participants are typically screened by a therapist to ensure fit with the group’s focus and safety.
procedure: Orientation and goal setting with the group.
Facilitated sharing and discussion guided by the therapist.
Practice of coping strategies or interpersonal skills.
Homework or reflection exercises between sessions.
sections.total_treatment_time: 8–12 weeks for structured groups; ongoing for open-ended support groups.

sections.treatment_phase: Group discussion, skill practice, role-play, or processing of interpersonal dynamics.
sections.post_session: Reflection, feedback, and assignment of practice activities.

immediate: Increased sense of support and belonging
short_term: Reduced symptoms of anxiety or depression
long_term: Sustained recovery from addiction or trauma symptoms

common: Emotional discomfort when sharing personal issues

relative: Unwillingness to engage in group setting

ideal_candidates: People experiencing depression, anxiety, or trauma
Those wanting to improve interpersonal skills
screening_required: Evaluation of risk and readiness for group participation

practitioner: Licensed mental health professionals trained in group therapy facilitation

studies: Yalom’s research highlights curative factors in groups such as universality, cohesion, and interpersonal learning.
Meta-analyses show group therapy is as effective as individual therapy for many conditions.
sections.limitations: Effectiveness depends on group composition and therapist skill; may not suit all individuals.

sections.typical_session_cost: $40–$100 per session (often less expensive than individual therapy)
sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered by insurance when medically indicated
sections.cost_effectiveness: Highly cost-effective due to shared therapist time and strong outcomes.

sections.children: Groups may focus on social skills or emotional regulation.
sections.adolescents: Effective for peer support and skill building.
sections.older-adults: Helps address loneliness, grief, and chronic illness.

items: Therapist must ensure group cohesion and safety.
Screening and matching participants increases effectiveness.
Confidentiality is critical for participant trust.

items.label: Yalom, I. D., & Leszcz, M. (2020). The Theory and Practice of Group Psychotherapy.
Burlingame, G. M., et al. (2013). Effectiveness of group therapy across conditions: A meta-analysis.

seo.title: Group Therapy | Evidence-Based Supportive Psychotherapy
seo.description: Group therapy provides peer support, skill building, and therapist-guided sessions for depression, anxiety, trauma, and more.
